tit.cmt: 漢字が同じで、意味によって読み方が「たいふ・だいふ・たゆう」と変わることを以下の文章内で説明すると長くなるので、タイトルに並べてみました。

sen.j: 大夫（たいふ）とは、中国の周代から春秋戦国時代にかけての身分を表す言葉で領地を持った貴族のことである。
sen.e: Taifu refers to a social status of nobility with territory from the Zhou period to the Spring, Autumn, and the Warring States periods in China.
Taifu refers to a social status of nobility with territory from the Zhou period to the Spring and Autumn period and the Warring States period in China.
sen.cmt: the Spring, Autumn, and the Warring States periods --> the Spring and Autumn period and the Warring States period
sen.e: Taifu refers to a social status of nobility with territory from the Zhou period to the Spring and Autumn period and the Warring States period in China.

sen.j: 大夫（だいぶ、たいふ）は、日本の律令制の長官名の一つ。
sen.e: Taifu/Daifu is one of the names of Kami (directors) in the ritsuryo system in Japan.
Taifu/Daifu is one of the names of Kami (directors) in the ritsuryo system in Japan.
Taifu/Daifu is one of the names of Kami (directors) in the ritsuryo system in Japan.

sen.j: 大夫（たゆう）は2.から転じて江戸時代、江戸吉原_(東京都)や京都嶋原の最高位の遊女を指す。
sen.e: Derived from No.2, Tayu refers to the highest rank Yujo (a courtesan) in Yoshiwara in Edo (Tokyo Prefecture), and Shimabara in Kyoto, in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: （※１）「2.から転じて」の部分は、元の原稿（Wiki)には記載されていて、この原文（original)では省かれている「２. 大夫（たいふ）とは、中国語で医者（:zh:大夫）のこと。医生（:zh:医生）とも言う。」を指していると思われます。「２」の文章を追記するか「2.から転じて」を削除する必要があると思われます。訳は原稿通りにしてあります。
sen.e: Derived from No.2, Tayu refers to the highest rank Yujo (a prostitute) in Yoshiwara in Edo (Tokyo Prefecture), and Shimabara in Kyoto, in the Edo period.
Derived from No.2, Tayu refers to the highest rank Yujo (a prostitute) in Yoshiwara in Edo (Tokyo Prefecture), and Shimabara in Kyoto, in the Edo period.

sen.j: 1754年（宝暦4年）に廃止され、江戸・吉原では以後名称は花魁（おいらん）と変わったが、京・島原では「大夫」の名称が残り、今でも数名の大夫が存在する。
sen.e: This name was abolished in 1754, and was later replaced by the name, Oiran (a prostitute) in Yoshihara in Edo, however, in Shimabara in Kyoto, the name 'Tayu' remained and some Tayu are still there.

This name was abolished in 1754, and was later replaced by the name, Oiran (a courtesan of the highest rank) in Yoshihara in Edo; however, the name 'Tayu' remained in Shimabara in Kyoto, where there are some still having the traditional name of Tayu.
sen.cmt: prostitutea をcourtesan of the highest rankに変更。現在の太夫は名前だけであり、いわゆるprostituteでもcourtesanでもないというニュアンスを訳に込めました。
sen.e: This name was abolished in 1754, and was later replaced by the name, Oiran (a courtesan of the highest rank) in Yoshihara in Edo; however, the name 'Tayu' remained in Shimabara in Kyoto, where there are some still having the traditional name of Tayu.

sen.j: →太夫（松の位）
sen.e: Refer to Tayu (the highest rank of courtesans).
Refer to 太夫 (the highest rank of courtesans).
sen.cmt: Tayu --> 太夫ここまでTayuの説明をしている最中に「Tayuを参照」では不自然と考え、「大夫」でなく「太夫」の項を参照という意味で修正を加えました。
sen.e: Refer to 太夫 (the highest rank of courtesans).

sen.j: 大夫（たゆう）は2.から転じて江戸時代以降、浄瑠璃の語り部を指す用語。
sen.e: Derived from No.2, Tayu refers to the storyteller of Joruri (dramatic narrative chanted to a samisen accompaniment) after the Edo period.

sen.j: 大夫は中国における身分呼称のひとつ。
sen.e: Taifu is one of the names of social status in China.

sen.j: 卿の下、士の上に位した。
sen.e: It was lower than Kyo (a minister) and higher than Shi (the elite class of Servicemen in the Zhou period).

sen.j: 周代、周王室および諸侯に仕える小領主は大夫と呼ばれ、その上級のものが卿と呼ばれ、国政に参加した。
sen.e: In the Zhou period, a small feudal lord who worked for the Zhou Dynasty or the lords was called Daibu (a master), and senior Daibu was called Kyo (a minister) and participated in governmental affairs.

sen.e: In the Zhou period, a small feudal lord who worked for the Zhou Dynasty or the lords was called Daibu (a master), and a senior Daibu was called Kyo (a minister) and participated in governmental affairs.

sen.j: 諸侯が横暴であった場合、大夫らにより追放されることもあり、主君を脅かし得る地位を得るようになった。
sen.e: When lords were autocratic, they were in some cases expelled by Daibu, resulting in Daibu gaining power to threaten their loads.

sen.j: 後代には大夫や士の中に衰退する者も現れたが、その後、有力農民層が新たに士という階級を形成し、地位を得るようになったといわれる。
sen.e: Although some Daibu and Kyo declined later, after that, powerful peasantry formed a rank, Shi, and gained status.

sen.j: 晋 (春秋)では地方の県のことを大夫と呼ぶようになり、後に諸国もこれに倣い、中央集権的な郡県制へと移行することになる。
sen.e: In the Jin Dynasty (the Spring and Autumn period), the local area became called Daibu, which was then followed by other districts, leading to the centralized county and prefecture system.

sen.j: 日本における大夫
sen.e: Taifu/Daifu in Japan

sen.j: 日本における大夫は、『公式令』により、太政官においては三位以上、寮においては四位以上、国司国等級区分以下の国司においては五位以上の官吏の称とされた。
sen.e: According to"Kushiki-ryo" (law on state documentary forms in the Yoro Code), Taifu referred to a government official with Sanmi (Third Rank) or higher in Daijokan (Grand Council of State), with Shii (Fourth Rank) or higher in Ryo (bureau), and with Goi (Fifth Rank) or higher among Kokushi (provincial governors) who were lower than 国司国等級区分 (the grade classification of Kuni [provinces] and Kokushi [provincial governors]).
sen.cmt: 「国司国等級区分」の読み方・定訳が分かりませんでした。 「the grade classification of Kuni [provinces] and Kokushi [provincial governors]」と説明しました。
sen.e: According to "Kushiki-ryo" (law on state documentary forms in the Yoro Code), Taifu referred to a government official of: Sanmi (Third Rank) or higher in Daijokan (Grand Council of State); Shii (Fourth Rank) or higher in Ryo (bureau); and Goi (Fifth Rank) or higher among Kokushi (provincial governors) who were lower than 国司国等級区分 (the grade classification of Kuni [provinces] and Kokushi [provincial governors]).
sen.cmt: a government official with のwithをofに変更、コロン（：）とセミコロン（；）を適宜挿入しました。。

sen.j: すなわち、五位以上の男性官吏を指す称号であるといってよい。

sen.j: 官職としての大夫はだいぶと読み、五位を意味する場合はたいふと読み分ける。
sen.e: As a governmental post, it is called Daibu, and when it refers to Goi, it is called Taifu.

sen.e: When a person with Rokui (Sixth Rank) or higher is conferred to Goi, Taifu is added to the end of his government position (If Saemon no jo [third-ranked officer of the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards] rises to Gojo, his job position becomes Saemon no taifu).
